content.description:
Climb the arete next to DynoWing on the Hallway boulder.

 Sit start, couple of bumps and some voodoo take you to the lip next to the tree. Good clean fun.

Begin sitting with a right hand flat undercling, left hand pocket/crimp, and a high right smear. Two moves get you established on the start of Tarantula. Do the first few moves of that problem, and move right through underclings to finish on the Snowblind dyno.
content.protection: Pads. A spotter is nice for the last move
content.location: The Tarantula boulder, on the same face.

content.description: Yeah it’s roadside, but the hike down 146 still kinda sucks. But this boulder problem doesn’t! Well it’s not the best, but you’re in Zanesville climbing so chill and have fun.
content.location:
From the Dillon Lakeside parking pin, hike towards Zanesville (lake on the right) until you see a large boulder on the right. Welcome to the Mammoth boulder! Hike down to the overhang, and continue about 100yds on a small trail with the lake on your right. 

 Sit start using a low large rail on the left. Use the pockets and pinches under the small roof to work out to small rail on the face. Find solid feet and reach for the top out.

content.description: Reachy, powerful moves on a steep overhang with few usuable features. Powerful compression moves to start, entering the crux almost immediately once you pull on the start crimps. Tarantula is nestled into the hillside and has an interesting walkable/climbable cave system underneath. Very fun. Very unique!
content.location: Sit start with feet on small chips under a ledge, hands on semi high crimps (if you’re short). Power up to an open hand crimp on a small slopey ledge, compress, match, catch feet and head to the undercling. Collect yo’self and power into small crimps leading to a large ledge at the top out.

content.description: Reach up to some incut holds facing the wrong way. Pull on and make big moves up the steep wall. Committing finish.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter would be nice for the last move
content.location: Starts to the right of "Tarantula" on some incut crimps surrounding the obvious rock scar (Previous starting hold)

content.description: The name says it all. Slip-N-Slide. Small holds, balancey moves and so much moss. Usually it’s green and actively growing moss. But once in a while, on a cool fall afternoon, after some careful brushing...it goes!
content.location: Stand start at the bottom of the slab, small crimps to start, use the mono and the arete to work upward.

content.description: Double jug start with good feet to a left hand horn, and from the one must use the vertical slot to stand up on the ledge and engage the crux. Easy slab to the top, which is a little heady.
content.location: Look for the tree near the route and the vertical slot on the slab.

content.description: Around the corner on the Tarantula Boulder. Start on the bottom left arete and move up and right to "The Rug". Just wipe your feet off or mom's gonna kill me!

Mammoth is a large boulder hosting multiple lines of varying difficulties. Not a fun hike, but a very easy hike. Head towards Zanesville (river on your right) until you see a large boulder over the guardrail on the right.
content.location: Start in the crack under the overhang at the base of the boulder. Continue to follow the crack until it ends and jugs appear.

content.description: In a hallway of doom and mosquitos a very unique problem lurks. The first visible boulders as you round the top of the hill from parking.
content.location: Sit start left, working the huecos out right through a horizontal series of heel and toe hooks. Land the big swing or beta ball your way through to the right side by the tree to top out.

content.description: Far right at the Lakeside set, in a hole, really close to the road. Also the home of a frequented geo cache.
content.location: Sit start using crimps/slots and small rails for feet. Work up on the arete out left and the slopers straight above. Once you’re to the sloper mantle, pick feet wisely and reach to the crimps above. Standing up will let you walk it out to the top. Wave to passing traffic. It’s always fun the looks they give!

content.description: Creeky emerges from the creek below Taratula. Makes a great warm up and has a lot of variations. I like to start my day at the lakeside set at Creeky, followed up by Tarantula and work my way boulder to boulder back to the truck.
content.location: I’m the creek below Tarantula. Careful not to get too wet getting to the start. Pockets and heal hooks on the blade lead to small foot chips and great holds above. Tons of variations. Top out around the corner.

content.description: Sit start on the obvious crimp jug (same start as dirt bags and dragons) middle of the boulder, compress and move straight up to the sloper, top out.
content.location: Middle of the Dirtbags and Dragons boulder. Straight up

content.description: Beautiful lakeside setting with surprisingly quality sandstone. Short, simple approach and volume of semi difficult moderates and a few hard lines. Try to keep party size and number of vehicles limited to avoid issues with the Rangers.
